awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Sampling the Ocean - Sea Ice Interaction in the Pacific Center of the Antarctic Dipole
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers from two leading US oceanographic institutions are to further investigate the response of the upper ocean of the eastern Ross Sea gyre to the ocean- sea ice - atmosphere feedbacks within the Pacific sector of the so-called 'Antarctic Dipole' climate pattern (ADP). The ADP is an interannual mode of climate variability observed in both sea ice cover and sea surface temperature. This variability appears as an out-of-phase relationship between anomalies in the Pacific (e.g. Ross Sea) and Atlantic sectors of the southern ocean (e.g. Weddell Sea). The ADP may also be linked to climatological anomalies seen in the central/eastern Pacific (e.g. El Nino Southern Oscillation, ENSO). 

Activities to take place include the deployment of moorings in the region of the Pacific ADP center in the eastern Ross Sea gyre to resolve upper ocean
(50~500m) stratification and velocity over timescales ranging from daily to the interannual. By deploying ice profiling sonar beacons at the top of the moorings, collocated measurements of sea-ice coverage and thickness will be made. During the deployment period, simultaneous German efforts will continue and extend complementary measurements in the Weddell gyre. The total measurement effort promises to increase our understanding of the southern ocean's role in both the hemispheric air-sea ice system, and the connections to global scale climate variability.

Outcomes Report on “Collaborative Research: Sampling the ocean - sea ice interaction in the Pacific center of the Antarctic Dipole” 

Xiaojun Yuan

November 14, 2014

 

The main goal of this program is to investigate the response of the upper ocean and the variability in the air-sea-ice system in the Pacific Center of the Antarctic Dipole (ADP) in the Southern Ocean. The ADP is a standing mode pattern characterized by out-of-phase relationships in the surface air temperature, sea surface temperature, and sea ice fields. The opposing large-scale spatial patterns of the ADP within the Pacific and Atlantic centers are closely associated with both positive and negative phases of El Nino/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) in the tropics. Specifically, we are motivated by the desire to better understand the local and regional processes underlying the response of the ADP to climate forcing on synoptic to ENSO time scales. Our key goal is to determine the role of the upper ocean in maintaining the ADP climate signal in the Southern Ocean. To achieve this goal, multi-year mooring deployments were planned in the Pacific Center of ADP near the western Amundsen Sea. This mooring was designed to resolve the upper ocean stratification and velocity over a variety of time scales from daily to interannual.

Although the research area is climatically and scientifically important, it is operationally difficult due to its remoteness, its approximate 4700m water depth and its seasonal ice cover with large interannual variability. During a five-year period, after two attempts, we successfully deployed and recovered this deep ocean mooring measuring upper ocean temperature, salinity and current for the period of 4/2011 to 3/2013.  The mooring consists of 12 temperature, salinity and current sensors that were mounted evenly between 140 to 250m depth at the upper part of the mooring, and a moving profiler traveling between 250 to 1200m depth. One of temperature-pressure sensors was placed at the bottom of the mooring at the depth of 4655m, measuring the variability of the total water column.  Ninety percent of the instruments placed on the mooring worked properly during the deployment, yielding 719 days of sampling with high temporal resolutions ranging from 30 minutes to one day.  These data represents the first subsurface oceanic time series in the subpolar deep ocean of the South Pacific. Our preliminary examination of the data found a subsurface cooling in the austral summer at this location, which has not been detected before. These data are currently being used for the Southern Ocean State Estimation (SOSE). In addition, they provide extremely valuable data for scientific investigations in the area years to come.

In addition to this deep ocean mooring sampling, we have collected ship-based sampling of temperature and salinity profiles (CTD, XBT samplings) during the deployment and recovery cruises in the vicinity of the mooring site. We also collect oceanic data from other monitoring programs in the area, including ARGO floats and seal data. Together with publically available satellite sea ice, sea surface temperature observations and atmospheric re-analysis datasets, we have compiled an extensive dataset that are ready for the next step of scientific investigation.

With the support of this program, we have produced 6 peer-reviewed publications. These studies address the interruption of ADP signal propagation around Antarctica, ADP/ENSO impacts on the variability of Weddell Sea Bottom Water, impact of climate patterns on Antarctic coastal polynyas, decadal variability in the Southern Ocean, etc. Details regarding these studies and about this program can be found in the project website: http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~xyuan/ADPmo...
